content-security-policy.name: content-security-policy
content-security-policy.score_description: Content Security Policy (CSP) implemented unsafely. This includes 'unsafe-inline' or data: inside script-src, overly broad sources such as https: inside object-src or script-src, or not restricting the sources for object-src or script-src.

contribute.name: contribute
contribute.score_description: Contribute.json isn't required on websites that don't belong to Mozilla

cookies.name: cookies
cookies.score_description: All cookies use the Secure flag, session cookies use the HttpOnly flag, and cross-origin restrictions are in place via the SameSite flag

cross-origin-resource-sharing.name: cross-origin-resource-sharing
cross-origin-resource-sharing.score_description: Content is not visible via cross-origin resource sharing (CORS) files or headers

public-key-pinning.name: public-key-pinning
public-key-pinning.score_description: HTTP Public Key Pinning (HPKP) header cannot be set, as site contains an invalid certificate chain

redirection.name: redirection
redirection.score_description: Not able to connect via HTTP, so no redirection necessary

strict-transport-security.name: strict-transport-security
strict-transport-security.score_description: HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) header cannot be set, as site contains an invalid certificate chain

subresource-integrity.name: subresource-integrity
subresource-integrity.score_description: Subresource Integrity (SRI) not implemented, but all scripts are loaded from a similar origin

x-frame-options.name: x-frame-options
x-frame-options.score_description: X-Frame-Options (XFO) header set to SAMEORIGIN or DENY

technologies.name: React
technologies.description: React is an open-source JavaScript library for building user interfaces or UI components.

technologies.name: JSS
technologies.description: JSS is an authoring tool for CSS which allows you to use JavaScript to describe styles in a declarative, conflict-free and reusable way.

technologies.name: Nginx
technologies.description: Nginx is a web server that can also be used as a reverse proxy, load balancer, mail proxy and HTTP cache.

technologies.name: Matomo Analytics
technologies.description: Matomo Analytics is a free and open-source web analytics application, that runs on a PHP/MySQL web-server.

technologies.name: Lodash
technologies.description: Lodash is a JavaScript library which provides utility functions for common programming tasks using the functional programming paradigm.

technologies.name: core-js
technologies.description: core-js is a modular standard library for JavaScript, with polyfills for cutting-edge ECMAScript features.

technologies.name: HSTS
technologies.description: HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) informs browsers that the site should only be accessed using HTTPS.

technologies.name: Webpack
technologies.description: Webpack is an open-source JavaScript module bundler.

technologies.name: PWA
technologies.description: Progressive Web Apps (PWAs) are web apps built and enhanced with modern APIs to deliver enhanced capabilities, reliability, and installability while reaching anyone, anywhere, on any device, all with a single codebase.

technologies.name: Module Federation
technologies.description: Module Federation is a webpack technology for dynamically loading parts of other independently deployed builds.

alerts.name: CSP: Wildcard Directive
alerts.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks. Including (but not limited to) Cross Site Scripting (XSS), and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page — covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

alerts.name: CSP: script-src unsafe-inline
alerts.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks. Including (but not limited to) Cross Site Scripting (XSS), and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page — covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

alerts.name: CSP: style-src unsafe-inline
alerts.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks. Including (but not limited to) Cross Site Scripting (XSS), and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page — covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

alerts.name: CSP: Notices
alerts.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks. Including (but not limited to) Cross Site Scripting (XSS), and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page — covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

alerts.name: Cookie with SameSite Attribute None
alerts.desc: A cookie has been set with its SameSite attribute set to "none", which means that the cookie can be sent as a result of a 'cross-site' request. The SameSite attribute is an effective counter measure to cross-site request forgery, cross-site script inclusion, and timing attacks.

alerts.name: Dangerous JS Functions
alerts.desc: A dangerous JS function seems to be in use that would leave the site vulnerable.

alerts.name: Permissions Policy Header Not Set
alerts.desc: Permissions Policy Header is an added layer of security that helps to restrict from unauthorized access or usage of browser/client features by web resources. This policy ensures the user privacy by limiting or specifying the features of the browsers can be used by the web resources. Permissions Policy provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to limit which features of browsers can be used by the page such as camera, microphone, location, full screen etc.

alerts.name: Server Leaks Version Information via "Server" HTTP Response Header Field
alerts.desc: The web/application server is leaking version information via the "Server" HTTP response header. Access to such information may facilitate attackers identifying other vulnerabilities your web/application server is subject to.

alerts.name: X-Content-Type-Options Header Missing
alerts.desc: The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.

alerts.name: Base64 Disclosure
alerts.desc: Base64 encoded data was disclosed by the application/web server. Note: in the interests of performance not all base64 strings in the response were analyzed individually, the entire response should be looked at by the analyst/security team/developer(s).

alerts.name: Information Disclosure - Suspicious Comments
alerts.desc: The response appears to contain suspicious comments which may help an attacker. Note: Matches made within script blocks or files are against the entire content not only comments.

alerts.name: Modern Web Application
alerts.desc: The application appears to be a modern web application. If you need to explore it automatically then the Ajax Spider may well be more effective than the standard one.

alerts.name: Non-Storable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are not storable by caching components such as proxy servers. If the response does not contain sensitive, personal or user-specific information, it may benefit from being stored and cached, to improve performance.

alerts.name: Re-examine Cache-control Directives
alerts.desc: The cache-control header has not been set properly or is missing, allowing the browser and proxies to cache content. For static assets like css, js, or image files this might be intended, however, the resources should be reviewed to ensure that no sensitive content will be cached.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Dest Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies how and where the data would be used. For instance, if the value is audio, then the requested resource must be audio data and not any other type of resource.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Mode Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Allows to differentiate between requests for navigating between HTML pages and requests for loading resources like images, audio etc.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Site Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies the relationship between request initiator's origin and target's origin.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-User Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies if a navigation request was initiated by a user.

alerts.name: Session Management Response Identified
alerts.desc: The given response has been identified as containing a session management token. The 'Other Info' field contains a set of header tokens that can be used in the Header Based Session Management Method. If the request is in a context which has a Session Management Method set to "Auto-Detect" then this rule will change the session management to use the tokens identified.

alerts.name: Storable and Cacheable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are storable by caching components such as proxy servers, and may be retrieved directly from the cache, rather than from the origin server by the caching servers, in response to similar requests from other users. If the response data is sensitive, personal or user-specific, this may result in sensitive information being leaked. In some cases, this may even result in a user gaining complete control of the session of another user, depending on the configuration of the caching components in use in their environment. This is primarily an issue where "shared" caching servers such as "proxy" caches are configured on the local network. This configuration is typically found in corporate or educational environments, for instance.

info.name: MX Record Detection
author: pdteam
info.description: An MX record was detected. MX records direct emails to a mail exchange server.

info.name: DNS TXT Record Detected
author: pdteam
info.description: A DNS TXT record was detected. The TXT record lets a domain admin leave notes on a DNS server.

info.name: HttpOnly Cookie - Detect
author: mr. bobo hp
info.description: Checks whether cookies in the HTTP response contain the HttpOnly attribute. If the HttpOnly flag is set, it means that the cookie is HTTP-only

info.name: Detect SSL Certificate Issuer
author: lingtren
info.description: Extract the issuer's organization from the target's certificate. Issuers are entities which sign and distribute certificates.

info.name: SSL DNS Names
author: pdteam
info.description: Extract the Subject Alternative Name (SAN) from the target's certificate. SAN facilitates the usage of additional hostnames with the same certificate.

info.name: TLS Version - Detect
author: pdteam
pussycat0x
info.description:
TLS version detection is a security process used to determine the version of the Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol used by a computer or server.
It is important to detect the TLS version in order to ensure secure communication between two computers or servers.

info.name: TLS Version - Detect
author: pdteam
pussycat0x
info.description:
TLS version detection is a security process used to determine the version of the Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol used by a computer or server.
It is important to detect the TLS version in order to ensure secure communication between two computers or servers.

info.name: Expired SSL Certificate
author: pdteam
info.description: After an SSL certificate expires, you will no longer be able to communicate over a secure, encrypted HTTPS connection.
info.remediation: Purchase or generate a new SSL/TLS certificate to replace the existing one.

info.name: Revoked SSL Certificate - Detect
author: pussycat0x
info.description: Certificate revocation is the act of invalidating a TLS/SSL before its scheduled expiration date. A certificate should be revoked immediately when its private key shows signs of being compromised. It should also be revoked when the domain for which it was issued is no longer operational.
